items.title: Safari getting lazy loading image support
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹517 â€” November 17, 2021 | Read on the web

What's New in Lighthouse 9.0 â€” Version 9.0 of Googleâ€™s popular website auditing tool arrives with a refreshed report and a preview of support for user flows. Itâ€™s available in Chrome Canary now, and will land in the stable release of ChromeÂ 98.

Brendan Kenny

Powerful Terminal and Command-Line (CLI) Tools for Modern Web Development â€” Whatâ€™s your favorite command-line tool? In this post, Louis shares a collection of relevant command-line apps and utilities that he has personally come across in the past fewÂ years.

Louis Lazaris

Video API Built to Create Stunning Visual Experiences â€” Are videos impacting your page's load time? Now, deliver optimized videos in the right format, quality & size based on the user's device in real-time. Delivering stunning visual experiences just got simpler, Try ImageKit's forever-free planÂ today.

ImageKit.io sponsor

Release Notes for Safari Technology Preview 135 â€” Here are the release notes for the latest preview build of Safari, which is available now. Most notably this version adds lazy loading image support, along with support for accent-color, the requestVideoFrameCallback API, and new viewport units.

Jon Davis (Apple)

Using Position Sticky with CSS Grid â€” Explains how the default CSS grid stretch behavior affects position: sticky, and how to override it to make it work asÂ expected.

Ahmad Shadeed

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Version 96 of Chrome is rolling out now, so here's what's new in DevTools.
  • You can now download Firefox directly from the Windows Store.
  • Chris Siebenmann details how both Edge and Chrome may start restricting requests to private networks in order to resolve a security threat.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Using Web Workers to Boost Third-Party Script Performance â€” A look at Partytown, a new experimental library that aims to improve third-party script performance using Web WorkerÂ technology.

Arek Nawo

â–¶Â Â Responsive Navbar Tutorial using HTML, CSS & JS â€” Iâ€™ve always found creating navigation components a bit of a pain so any pointers or help is alwaysÂ welcome.

Kevin Powell

Put the â€œFlowâ€ in Your Workflows with Shortcut â€” Looking for an intuitive white-board style project management tool? Collaboration has never been easier withÂ Shortcut.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Why Your Website Should Not Use Dithered Images â€” â€œDespite claims that dithered images will reduce your imageâ€™s file size, there are much better ways to compress your websiteâ€™sÂ imagesâ€. Once upon a time, color depth limitations on displays made dithering desirable, but this is rarely the caseÂ anymore.

Austin Carr

Your CSS is an Interface â€” How human-friendly CSS class names can help someone use your website or webÂ app.

Eric Bailey

â€œAMP Has Irreparably Damaged Publishersâ€™ Trust in Google-led Initiativesâ€
Sarah Gooding opinion

Generate a Pull Request of Static Content with a Simple HTML Form
Hilman Ramadhan

Jobs

Frontend Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Grow a Design System at Addepar â€” Work with a talented team of designers and engineers on the foundation for Addeparâ€™s expanding UX. Weâ€™re building tools that keep our customer experience one of the best inÂ Fintech.
Addepar

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

Splide: Lightweight and Accessible Slider/Carousel â€” Itâ€™s nice to see a clean, modern spin on the often maligned UI element. The homepage is packed with demos too. No dependencies, written in TypeScript, and boasts a clean report from Lighthouse. GitHubÂ repo.

Naotoshi Fujita

CSS Shadow Palette Generator â€” A tool to help you create lush, realistic shadows in CSS. box-shadow can look fantastic, but can require a bunch of crafty tricks. This tool builds those tricks in, and makes them easy toÂ use.

John W. Comeau

Visualize Your IoT Data with Highcharts and InfluxDB

InfluxData sponsor

couleur.io: A Simple Tool to Build Harmonious Color Palettes â€” Based on HSL color values and it spits out a palette of 10 color values of varying lightness levels but using a common hue and saturation level, thus the palette isÂ â€˜harmonizedâ€™.

couleur.io

IconKitchen: Mobile App Icon Generator â€” An interactive UI to customize your app icon with clipart, text, custom image, plus various settings for icon type, color, gradient, padding, etc., before downloading a ZIPÂ file.

Roman Nurik

TuiCss: A Text-Based User Interface CSS Library â€” If youâ€™re old enough to remember what DOS apps looked like (or, arguably, some Linux shell ones, even now) this may appeal to you. Get Borland Turbo Vision-esque visuals but on the web withÂ this. Is it a good idea? LessÂ sure.

Vinicius Reif Biavatti

Vant: 65+ Mobile UI Components Built with Vue & TypeScript
youzan

tailwindcss-aria-attributes: Tailwind Variants for aria-* Attributes
thoughtbot

items.title: The highlights from Chrome Dev Summit
items.content:
ğŸ‘‹ Hey folks. The Chrome Dev Summit took place last week, as such a fair few of the items this week link to news / articles off the back of that. Thanks for reading!
__
Chris Brandrick, your editor

Frontend Focus

#â€‹516 â€” November 10, 2021 | Read on the web

Everything Announced at Chrome Dev Summit 2021 â€” A roundup of all the key announcements from the 2021 Chrome Dev Summit, with the links you need to find outÂ more. Una Kravets has a succint five-minute recap video here if you'd prefer that.

  • There's a new Lighthouse API to measure performance and best practices throughout a user flow.
  • An updated version of PageSpeed Insights is on the way, this post looks at what's new.
  • The Chrome Speed Metrics Team are seeking feedback on plans to measure responsiveness on the web.
  • This post highlights recent progress made towards an animation smoothness metric.
  • Richard MacManus of The New Stack shares his thoughts on Googleâ€™s Chrome DevÂ Summit, calling it a 'web evolution, notÂ revolution'.

Rachel Andrew

The Browser Wars â€” Jayâ€™s excellent long-running Web History series returns, this time with a focus on the fierce browser wars of the late 90s amongst the likes of Microsoft, Netscape, andÂ Mozilla.

Jay Hoffmann

Implementing Batch Editing in an Angular Data Grid the Easy Way â€” Use this tutorial to learn how to use Kendo UI for Angular to create a Data Grid that allows updates and saves inÂ bulk.

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Chrome's New Feature to Record and Replay User Flows â€” Itâ€™s only a preview feature in Canary builds right now, but Chrome is adding a new Recorder panel to its DevTools which lets you record and replay a string of actions on a page (including under simulated slow network conditions). You can also measure the flow and get a performance trace forÂ analysis. Minko Gechev shared a video of it in action over on Twiter.

Jecelyn Yeen (Google)

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • The W3C's Annual Conference also took place last month over five days, and now the full archive of all the breakout sessions is online, complete with slides and video. You're bound to find something worth watching here â€”Â I just got done with Uchi Uchibeke's talk on the Web Monetization API.
  • Dev browser Polypane just hit version 7 bringing with it a slew of new features â€”Â including a system-wide color picker, prefers-contrast emulation support and live editing of pseudo elements across all viewports.
  • The second alpha of Tailwind CSS version 3 is out if you fancy battle-testing it a bit before the final release.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

'We Analyzed 425,909 Favicons' â€” An interesting bit of work here digging into the current favicon ecosystem by fetching and analysing the favicons of the top 100,000 websites. You can see a map of all the favicons fetchedÂ here.

Adam, Nathan & Patrick

Eye-Tracking in Mobile UX Research â€” Explores the latest trends in eye-tracking and how the methodology can be included in the UX researcherâ€™sÂ toolbox.

Mariana Macedo

Put the â€œFlowâ€ in Your Workflows with Shortcut â€” Looking for an intuitive white-board style project management tool? Collaboration has never been easier withÂ Shortcut.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

How to Implement and Style the <dialog> Element â€” An in-depth look at the native HTML dialog element, showing you how to implement a user-friendly, accessible version on yourÂ site.

Christian Kozalla

First Steps with GPT-3 for Frontend Developers â€” Consider this a beginners guide to OpenAIâ€™s API, easing frontend devs into the world of GPT-3 and giving you a heads-up on all the tools needed to start building AI-poweredÂ apps.

Maxime Heckel

A Beginner's Guide to Responsive Images â€” Includes live demos and code snippets introducing syntax for the srcset and sizes attributes and the <picture> element, for developers getting started with responsiveÂ images.

Louis Lazaris beginner

Creating the Effect of Transparent Glass and Plastic with Three.js â€” The effects you can pull off in the browser nowadays continue to impress me as someone who grew up on 8-bitÂ graphics(!).

Kelly Milligan

Learn Responsive Design â€” This course is an excellent primer exploring all contemporary aspects of responsiveÂ design.

Jeremy Keith beginner

Favicons: How to Make Sure Browsers Only Download the SVG Version
Chris Coyier (via Å ime Vidas)

If HTML and ARIA Donâ€™t Allow It, Itâ€™s Probably A Bad Idea
Martin Underhill

Optimizing Resource Loading with Priority Hints
Sohoni, Osmani, Meenan

Native CSS Nesting: What You Need to Know
Sarah Chima Atuonwu

An Introduction to PostCSS
Craig Buckler

Jobs

Senior Web Developer (Node/ReactJS) - Remote â€” Millions get inspired and plan adventures with our apps. To help us make komoot.com the place to go to plan outdoor adventures, weâ€™re looking for a one of a kind Web Developer to join ourÂ team.
Komoot

[EU] JavaScript Developer, Preferably with React Knowledge â€” New hires get a "buddy" who will guide you through the company, code and the process. Newest technologies, development possibilities and satisfactionÂ :)
LastMinute.com

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

ssshape: An SVG Blob/Organic Shape Generator with Extra Controls â€” Choose a few random points, then this tool will generate a blob that you can adjust with numerous settings, then copy/export in SVGÂ format. Quite a decent variety of options/outputs here.

SÃ©bastien NoÃ«l

Iconsax: 6000 Free Icons in Six Different Styles â€” This huge collection of icons is available in multiple styles and design-friendly formats. Thereâ€™s also a React version and an accompanying component framework forÂ Vue.

Lusaxweb

Automate Domains, DNS, and SSL Certificates with This Special Offer ğŸ‘€

DNSimple sponsor

Compressio: An Open Source Image Compression Tool â€” Another option for batch image optimization (JPG, PNG, GIF & SVG). Allows 10 images/50MB at a time and includes a quality slider and settings to toggle lossless compression and metadataÂ retention.

Choudhary Abdullah

MiniMasonry.js: Minimalist Dependancy Free Masonry Layout Library

Spope

items.title: Edge puts on a Tux
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹515 â€” November 3, 2021 | Read on the web

Microsoftâ€™s Edge Browser Now Stable on Linux â€” After over a year in preview, the stable version of Edge for Linux is now available. Here's the official blog post from Microsoft covering the news. This release means Edge is now available on Windows, macOS, iOS, Android, and Linux.

Tom Warren

Web Performance Metrics Cheatsheet â€” A succinct, handy summary of web performance metrics (such as Time to First Byte, Largest Contentful Paint, Time to Interactive, etc). Also available as aÂ PDF.

Ire Aderinokun

New Frontend Masters Course on CSS Grid & Flexbox â€” Learn essential layout techniques for building responsive, beautiful web apps. Get hands-on practice using CSS Grid for two-dimensional, grid-based layouts and Flexbox for styling one-directionalÂ flow.

Frontend Masters sponsor

How I Made Googleâ€™s Data Grid Scroll 10x Faster with One LineÂ ofÂ CSS â€” If you're not familiar with the idea of CSS containment (now widely supported by browsers) and how it can improve the efficiency of a layout, this might be an eye opener.

Johan Isaksson

â–¶Â Â Developer Tools Secrets That Shouldnâ€™t Be Secrets â€” An Edge-focused look at console power tips, how to use browser developer tools outside the browser, andÂ more.

Christian Heilmann

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Version 94 of Firefox is now available. Here are the notes for developers.
  • You can expect accessibility improvements, bug fixes and a re-implementation of Sass division functions in version 4.6.1 of Bootstrap.
  • WebAssembly Dynamic Tiering is ready to try in Chrome 96.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

CSS-ing Candy Ghost Buttons â€” Highlights a technique for creating outlined buttons with CSS. They look simple enough, but thereâ€™s a few things worth taking into consideration to get them looking right. Ana outlines theÂ solutions.

Ana Tudor

Respecting Usersâ€™ Motion Preferences â€” The prefers-reduced-motion media query has excellent support in all modern browsers going back a couple of years. In this article, Michelle Barker explains why thereâ€™s no reason not to use it today to make your sites moreÂ accessible.

Michelle Barker

Using CSS Variables for Reduced Motion on a Global Scale â€” How to use CSS Variable and the prefers-reduced-motion media feature to remove or minimize animations and transitions on globalÂ scale.

Silvestar BistroviÄ‡

â–¶Â Â Have Single-Page Apps 'Ruined' the Web? â€” An excellent, and clear talk from the creator of frontend framework Svelte talking about the often-valid criticisms lodged towards single-page apps and how â€˜transitional appsâ€™ may be a wayÂ forward.

Rich Harris

â€œWe talk about documents versus apps as though it were a dichotomy, but it's not, it's a spectrum. When we erase the stuff in the middle we do the web a great disservice. It's a medium that by its very nature resists definitional boundaries.â€

___
Rich Harris

Put the â€œFlowâ€ in Your Workflows with Shortcut â€” Shortcut is fast and intuitive project management built for developers. Delight the scrum gods and try itÂ now.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

The Golden Ratio and User-Interface Design â€” Although traditionally used in art and architecture, the golden ratio can be referenced to design aesthetically pleasingÂ interfaces.

Kelley Gordon

The Process of Building a CSS Framework â€” A behind-the-scenes look at making a CSS framework (specifically CodyFrame) and a tutorial on how to build a website withÂ it.

Claudia Romano

Best Practices for Embedding Third-Party Web Widgets
Ravidu Perera

Render Images Based on the Dark or Light Theme of the Client Device
Amit Merchant

Jobs

Frontend Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Work From Anywhere in the World: Remote Sr. Front-End Engineer â€” B2B SaaS company seeks engineers who love building interactive data apps, being a part of a global community, and great hotÂ sauce.
Chili Piper

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

Coding Font: A 'Game' to Find Your New Favorite Code Font â€” This is a fun idea. It throws over 25 popular developer-oriented fonts into a â€˜tournamentâ€™ and you then pick your favorites until youâ€™re left with a winner. (It was JetBrains Mono forÂ me.)

Typogram

Fontfacer â€” Autogenerate CSS Font Rules from Font Files â€” Takes your uploaded font files and generates a list of CSS font rules for you to copy and paste into yourÂ codebase.

Peter White

Vizzu: A Library for Animated Data Visualizations and Data Stories â€” Vizzu is a little different to most data visualization libraries in the sense that animating the visualizations and transforming between different visualization types is the keyÂ focus.

Vizzu

Automate Domains, DNS, and SSL Certificates with This SpecialÂ OfferÂ ğŸ‘€

DNSimple sponsor

Lorem.space: An API for Placeholder Images â€” Two nice features for this one: You can choose from various categories (to match the type of website) and download binaries to serve the images yourself for localÂ development.

Pouya Saadeghi

Ninja Keys: A Utility to Add a Keyboard Shortcuts Interface to a Website â€” Will display a â€˜drawerâ€™ with shortcut key options for the app/page, available in plain JS, Vue, React, and Svelte. Try itÂ here.

Sergei Sleptsov

Hasty: A JavaScript Perfomance Tool â€” A quick, easy-to-use online tool that lets you test variations of a particular snippet to see which one performsÂ best.

Mads Cordes

Core Web Vitals Checker â€” Check if your site meets the Core Web Vitals assessment in oneÂ click.

Calibre
items.contentSnippet:
Frontend Focus
#â€‹515 â€” November 3, 2021 | Read on the web



  





  
  
Microsoftâ€™s Edge Browser Now Stable on Linux â€” After over a year in preview, the stable version of Edge for Linux is now available. Here's the official blog post from Microsoft covering the news. This release means Edge is now available on Windows, macOS, iOS, Android, and Linux.
Tom Warren 


  
  
Web Performance Metrics Cheatsheet â€” A succinct, handy summary of web performance metrics (such as Time to First Byte, Largest Contentful Paint, Time to Interactive, etc). Also available as aÂ PDF.
Ire Aderinokun 


  
  
New Frontend Masters Course on CSS Grid & Flexbox â€” Learn essential layout techniques for building responsive, beautiful web apps. Get hands-on practice using CSS Grid for two-dimensional, grid-based layouts and Flexbox for styling one-directionalÂ flow.
Frontend Masters sponsor


  
  
How I Made Googleâ€™s Data Grid Scroll 10x Faster with One LineÂ ofÂ CSS â€” If you're not familiar with the idea of CSS containment (now widely supported by browsers) and how it can improve the efficiency of a layout, this might be an eye opener.
Johan Isaksson 


  
  
â–¶Â Â Developer Tools Secrets That Shouldnâ€™t Be Secrets â€” An Edge-focused look at console power tips, how to use browser developer tools outside the browser, andÂ more.
Christian Heilmann 





âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:
Version 94 of Firefox is now available. Here are the notes for developers.
You can expect accessibility improvements, bug fixes and a re-implementation of Sass division functions in version 4.6.1 of Bootstrap.
 
                  
                  
WebAssembly Dynamic Tiering is ready to try in Chrome 96.






ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion




  





  
  
CSS-ing Candy Ghost Buttons â€” Highlights a technique for creating outlined buttons with CSS. They look simple enough, but thereâ€™s a few things worth taking into consideration to get them looking right. Ana outlines theÂ solutions.
Ana Tudor 


  
  
Respecting Usersâ€™ Motion Preferences â€” The prefers-reduced-motion media query has excellent support in all modern browsers going back a couple of years. In this article, Michelle Barker explains why thereâ€™s no reason not to use it today to make your sites moreÂ accessible.
Michelle Barker 


  
  
Using CSS Variables for Reduced Motion on a Global Scale â€” How to use CSS Variable and the prefers-reduced-motion media feature to remove or minimize animations and transitions on globalÂ scale.
Silvestar BistroviÄ‡ 


  
  
â–¶Â Â Have Single-Page Apps 'Ruined' the Web? â€” An excellent, and clear talk from the creator of frontend framework Svelte talking about the often-valid criticisms lodged towards single-page apps and how â€˜transitional appsâ€™ may be a wayÂ forward.
Rich Harris 




  
â€œWe talk about documents versus apps as though it were a dichotomy, but it's not, it's a spectrum. When we erase the stuff in the middle we do the web a great disservice. It's a medium that by its very nature resists definitional boundaries.â€
___
Rich Harris







  
  
Put the â€œFlowâ€ in Your Workflows with Shortcut â€” Shortcut is fast and intuitive project management built for developers. Delight the scrum gods and try itÂ now.
Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor


  
  
The Golden Ratio and User-Interface Design â€” Although traditionally used in art and architecture, the golden ratio can be referenced to design aesthetically pleasingÂ interfaces.
Kelley Gordon 


  
  
The Process of Building a CSS Framework â€” A behind-the-scenes look at making a CSS framework (specifically CodyFrame) and a tutorial on how to build a website withÂ it.
Claudia Romano 


  
Best Practices for Embedding Third-Party Web Widgets
  
Ravidu Perera 
  


  
Render Images Based on the Dark or Light Theme of the Client Device
  
Amit Merchant 
  








Jobs





  
Frontend Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
  
X-Team 
  


  
Work From Anywhere in the World: Remote Sr. Front-End Engineer â€” B2B SaaS company seeks engineers who love building interactive data apps, being a part of a global community, and great hotÂ sauce.
  
Chili Piper 
  


  
Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
  
Hired 
  







ğŸ”§  Code, Tools and Resources




  








  
  
Coding Font: A 'Game' to Find Your New Favorite Code Font â€” This is a fun idea. It throws over 25 popular developer-oriented fonts into a â€˜tournamentâ€™ and you then pick your favorites until youâ€™re left with a winner. (It was JetBrains Mono forÂ me.)
Typogram 


  
  
Fontfacer â€” Autogenerate CSS Font Rules from Font Files â€” Takes your uploaded font files and generates a list of CSS font rules for you to copy and paste into yourÂ codebase.
Peter White 


  
  
Vizzu: A Library for Animated Data Visualizations and Data Stories â€” Vizzu is a little different to most data visualization libraries in the sense that animating the visualizations and transforming between different visualization types is the keyÂ focus.
Vizzu 


  
  
Automate Domains, DNS, and SSL Certificates with This SpecialÂ OfferÂ ğŸ‘€
DNSimple sponsor


  
  
Lorem.space: An API for Placeholder Images â€” Two nice features for this one: You can choose from various categories (to match the type of website) and download binaries to serve the images yourself for localÂ development.
Pouya Saadeghi 


  
  
Ninja Keys: A Utility to Add a Keyboard Shortcuts Interface to a Website â€” Will display a â€˜drawerâ€™ with shortcut key options for the app/page, available in plain JS, Vue, React, and Svelte. Try itÂ here.
Sergei Sleptsov 


  
  
Hasty: A JavaScript Perfomance Tool â€” A quick, easy-to-use online tool that lets you test variations of a particular snippet to see which one performsÂ best.
Mads Cordes 


  
  
Core Web Vitals Checker â€” Check if your site meets the Core Web Vitals assessment in oneÂ click.
Calibre

items.title: Photoshop in the browser is now a reality.
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹514 â€” October 27, 2021 | Read on the web

A Deep Dive into object-fit and backgroundâ€‘size in CSS â€” Goes through just how object-fit and background-size work, when to use them, and why, along with some practical use cases andÂ recommendations.

Ahmad Shadeed

Photoshop's Journey to the Web â€” Just the idea of running software as complex as Photoshop directly in the browser would have been hard to imagine even just a few years ago, but here we are: Thanks to new standardized web technologies, Adobe has now brought a public beta of Photoshop to theÂ web. This opens up a lot of potential not just for Adobe but anyone with lofty browser-basedÂ ambitions.

Thomas Nattestad & Nabeel Al-Shamma

Walkthrough of an Easy Angular Data Grid with Examples â€” You could write your own data grid, but why would you when this one already exists. See how easy it is to set up, bind data, group, sort, page, and more. Fiddle with the live samples or install it and try it for yourself, but donâ€™t missÂ it.

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

New HTTP Standards for Caching on the Modern Web â€” Caching static content via a CDN or similar service is important, particularly for large sites, but can often be complicated and confusing. This post looks at new HTTP standards that are hoping to make this better, how they work, and why you shouldÂ care.

Tim Perry

The Start of a New Era for Responsive Web Design â€” After designing for fixed screens, and then responsively, the author proposes weâ€™re entering an era of â€˜component drivenâ€™ design.

Francois Brill

New WebKit Features in Safari 15 â€” A look at the new features available with the release of Safari 15.1, including aspect-ratio, CSS Grid Inspector, ES6 Modules in Workers and ServiceWorkers, WebGL2 andÂ more.

Jen Simmons

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • The hugely valuable Wayback Machine project from the Internet Archive got started 20-years ago this week.
  • Reminder: The State of CSS survey for 2021 is now open and seeking your response.
  • New material has been added to Google's Learn CSS course, including how to take advantage of CSS properties like ::marker and list-style.
  • As Lea points out here, the web probably needs its own Emoji picker.
  • A smart Web developer created a fake VS Code-esque Web page to keep an eye on the cricket scores.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Prevent Scroll Chaining with Overscroll Behaviour â€” Looks at the overscroll-behavior CSS property, what problem it solves, how it works, and where we can useÂ it.

Ahmad Shadeed

Building a Multi-Select Component â€” A foundational overview of how to build a responsive, adaptive, and accessible, multiselect component for sort and filter userÂ experiences.

Adam Argyle

How Not To Create a Menu Burger Button â€” A collection of bad practices in HTML - looking at menu buttons patterns, copied from realÂ websites.

Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡

Why 'Outdated' jQuery Is Still the Dominant JavaScript Library â€” jQuery is one of the longest running and most influential JavaScript libraries on the web. How has it stood the test ofÂ time?

Richard MacManus

â€œA staggering 78% of the top 1 million websites use jQuery in some way, according to BuiltWith.â€

___
Richard MacManus

"Dark Mode" vs "Inverted" â€” An approach to help clarify the difference between â€œdark modeâ€ and â€œcomponents rendered on a dark backgroundâ€ within your designÂ system.

Brad Frost

Building An Effective Image Component â€” An out-of-the-box solution to optimize images for Next.js. It optimizes loading, compression & responsiveness. Now with AVIF support in Next.jsÂ 12.

Sohoni, Erickson, Castle

Shortcut Puts the Agile in Agile and the â€œCanâ€ in Kanban

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

In-Page Filtered Search with Vanilla JavaScript

Hilman Ramadhan

100 Bytes of CSS to Look Great Everywhere

Shaun Wang

Expandable Sections Within a CSS Grid

Kev Bonett

Jobs

Work From Anywhere in the World: Remote Sr. Front-End Engineer â€” B2B SaaS company seeks engineers who love building interactive data apps, being a part of a global community, and great hotÂ sauce.
Chili Piper

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

Huetone: Use The LCH Color Space to Come Up with Predictable and Accessible Color Palettes â€” The creator explains the tool in detail in this TwitterÂ thread.

alexey ardov

Box Shadow Generator: A Visual Tool to Generate Code for CSS Box Shadows â€” You can choose from a gallery of predefined box shadow settings or create and customize yourÂ own.

Andrei Surdu

Free Activity Feeds & Chat APIs for Qualifying Teams â€” Unlock enterprise-grade features, functions, and UI components completely free for your startup or side project with the Maker Account fromÂ Stream.

Stream sponsor

Blobity: Level Up Your Cursor Game â€” This script and API lets you do all sorts of creative things with the userâ€™s cursor, which the page itself demonstrates â€” the demo is similar to how the cursor on iPad OS works. Note that itâ€™s free for open-source projectsÂ only.

Georgy Marchuk

Image Compressor: Compress & Optimize JPEG and PNGÂ Images â€” Yet another option for doing manual image compression. This one lets you upload multiple images and includes optional tools for resizing, converting, andÂ mirroring.

NAZRUL ISLAM

ğŸ“ Do you work with the Jamstack (that's a JavaScript, API and Markup architecture stack)? If so, you may enjoy Brian Rinaldi's JAMstacked, it's a fortnightly round-up covering the growing and rapidly evolving Jamstack ecosystem. Here's a little taste of the sorts of things shared in the latest issue:

Want to give it a try?
Tap here to subscribe
  • Matt Biilmann of Netlify discusses some key concepts that will impact the future of Jamstack with folks like Evan You, Rich Harris and more - from the recent Jamstack Conf.
  • It's often assumed that Jamstack or a serverless architecture are basically one and the same. This post from Colby Fayock breaks down the difference and shows how both can be combined.
  • Raymond Camden looks at the upgrade experience for Eleventy 1.0 (still in beta).

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
